Description:
Based on the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages but with extra details added to make it more suitable for ESP in higher education.

The extra compentencies are added at levels B2 and C1. It is considered that students at levels below B2 should be acquiring general English and high-frequency lexis from general Academic language.
Basic user - Beginner
Can understand and use familiar everyday expressions and very basic phrases aimed at the satisfaction of needs of a concrete type.
Can introduce him/herself and others and can ask and answer questions about personal details such as where he/she lives, people he/she knows and things he/she has.
Can interact in a simple way provided the other person talks slowly and clearly and is prepared to help.
Basic user - elementary
Can understand sentences and frequently used expressions related to areas of most immediate relevance (e.g. very basic personal and family information, shopping, local geography, employment).
Can communicate in simple and routine tasks requiring a simple and direct exchange of information on familiar and routine matters.
Can describe in simple terms aspects of his/her background, immediate environment and matters in areas of immediate need.
Independent user - Threshold
Can understand the main points of clear standard input on familiar matters regularly encountered in work, school, leisure, etc.
Can deal with most situations likely to arise while travelling in an area where the language is spoken.
Can produce simple connected text on topics that are familiar or of personal interest.
Can describe experiences and events, dreams, hopes and ambitions and briefly give reasons and explanations for opinions and plan
Independent user - Upper Intermediate
Listening — can understand spoken language in detail, including technical discussions in their field of specialization.
Listening — can understand the main ideas of spoken language on practical and abstract topics when delivered in standard language.
Listening — can use a variety of strategies to achieve comprehension such as listening for main points and using contextual clues.
Reading — can choose an appropriate reading strategy according to the situation eg skimming and scanning
Reading — can quickly identify subject matter, content and relevance of news items, articles and reports to decide which ones to study further
Reading — can read a text from their field of specialization and take part in a discussion about it
Reading — can read a text on a controversial question in their field and summarise the main points in it.
Reading — can use different strategies to deal with unknown words, eg. Guessing, using dictionaries and glossaries
Speaking — can successfully start, maintain and close a conversation
Speaking — can successfully exchange technical information within their field of specialization
Speaking — can describe and help to solve problems in their field of specialization
Speaking — can give clear descriptions of a wide range of topics related to their field of specialization
Speaking — can discuss the advantages and disadvantages of different solutions to problems in their field of specialization
Speaking — can explain the function of components in a piece of equipment or apparatus
Speaking — can discuss relevant skills and experience in a job interview
Writing - Can produce clear, detailed reports on issues in their field of specialization
Writing — can write a summary of an article, talk or discussion
Writing — can write explanatory notes and instructions for activities in their field of specialization
Interactions — can take part in a formal discussion, such as a committee meeting
Interactions — can maintain email correspondence in a professional way
Interactions — can prepare, design and present a short presentation in their field of specialization
study skills — can maintain a useful notebook of new words and phrases
study skills — can use recordings and texts for self study of the language
study skills — can reflect on and evaluate their own learning processes
Proficient user - effective operational proficiency (advanced)
Listening — can understand spoken language in detail, including complex technical discussions in their field of specialization.
Listening — can understand the main ideas of spoken language on practical and abstract topics even where there are problems like bad sound, unusual accents or colloquialisms.
Listening — can use a variety of strategies to achieve comprehension and evaluate the success of these strategies
Reading — can quickly identify the subject matter and line of argument in a text, differentiating the relevant and the irrelevant
Reading — can assess the relevance, novelty and reliability of longer texts in their field of specialization.
Reading — can read a text from their field of specialization and give a reasoned review of it
Reading — can read a text on a controversial question in their field and describe their own response to it.
Reading — can discuss difficulties of translation in their field of specialization
Speaking — can take part in long technical discussions within their field of specialization
Speaking — can provide clear instructions about how to solve problems in their field of specialization
Speaking — can explain and teach their colleagues a wide range of ideas related to their field of specialization
Speaking — can persuade their colleagues to adopt particular solutions to problems in their field of specialization
Speaking — can discuss and specify problems with a piece of equipment or apparatus
Speaking — can perform well in a job interview
Writing — write ordinary business letters relating to their field of specialization
Writing — can write a job application and CV
Writing — can write a text giving their argument relating to a specific problem in their field of specialization, and describing the problem in detail
Interactions — can play an important role in a formal discussion, such as chair or secretary
Interactions — can check their colleagues' writing and help to improve it
Interactions — can prepare, design and present a serious and in-depth presentation in their field of specialization
study skills — can collaborate on constructing knowledge with a wiki
study skills — can use online forums, blogs and networks to develop a personal learning environment
study skills — can describe their learning styles and habits in a useful and interesting way
Proficient user - Mastery
Can understand with ease virtually everything heard or read.
Can summarize information from different spoken and written sources, reconstructing arguments and accounts in a coherent presentation.
Can express him/herself spontaneously, very fluently and precisely, differentiating finer shades of meaning even in the most complex situations.
